column1: ";Although a year has passed since the Barguna launch fire tragedy
column2: families still mourn their missing loved ones. A devastating fire broke out at Barguna-bound launch ‘MV-Avijan-10’ on December 24 last year. The launch
column3: with 800 passengers on board
column4: was heading towards Barguna and the fire broke out on Sugandha river in Jhalakathi. Forty-nine people died in the tragedy while the exact numbers of passengers traveling on the launch and the missing passengers are yet to be known. One hundred people were injured in the incident.  Many did not get any compensation for what they lost during the fire. Besides
column5: families of missing passengers say no financial assistance has been provided to them. After the fire
column6: the local administration of Barguna district handed over 25 bodies to their relatives while 23 people were buried in a mass graveyard in the district. Khalil
column7: along with his wife and three children
column8: was heading towards Barguna by the launch. Khalil and his wife managed to survive but they still mourn their three missing children. Meanwhile
column9: Golam Mahbub’s offspring and elderly mother are inconsolable after losing him and his brother during the launch fire. Criminal Investigation Department (CID) collected samples of 51 people for identifying the 23 unclaimed bodies that were buried in Potkakhali mass graveyard in the Sadar upazila of Barguna district. Sixteen eople have been identified through DNA test. A case with Barguna Chief Judicial Magistrate Court against the owner of MV Avijan-10
column10: Hamjalal Sheikh
column11: and 24 others in connection with the deadly fire on the launch has been lodged
column12: said Shahidul Islam Milon
column13: inspector (Investigation) of Barguna police station.

column1: 20220824;20220824;NA;Motorcycle Accident Prevention: Tips to Reduce the Risk of a Crash;"<div class=""text"">
Motorcycles have many features that make them attractive to riders
column2: and they can also be dangerous if not ridden properly. Motorcycle accidents are one of the leading causes of death on the road. According to a research in 2016
column3: motorcycles are responsible for 28% of global fatalities on the roads.

column1: Motorbike accidents can be catastrophic
column2: often resulting in serious injury or death. While there is no guarantee that you will never have an accident if you ride a motorcycle
column3: following some simple safety tips can help reduce your risk of crashing. Let’s check out some prevention tips to help keep you safe on the road.

column4: sans-serif; color: #0e101a; background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">10 Safety Tips to Minimise the Risk of Motorbike accident

column2: Helvetica
column3: sans-serif; line-height: 1.2; margin-top: 10pt; margin-bottom: 10pt;""><strong><span style=""font-size: 14pt; font-family: Calibri
column4: sans-serif; background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Always Wear a Helmet

column1: A helmet is your first and most important line of defence in the event of a crash. And can help to reduce the risk of brain injury. In addition
column2: helmets can also help to protect your face from the elements and from flying debris. When choosing a helmet
column3: be sure to select one that meets DOT safety standards and that fits snugly on your head. Wearing a helmet is one of the best ways to reduce your risk of being injured in a motorcycle accident.

column3: sans-serif; line-height: 1.2; margin-top: 10pt; margin-bottom: 10pt;""><strong><span style=""font-size: 14pt; font-family: Calibri
column4: sans-serif; background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Always Wear Protective Gear

column1: In addition to a helmet
column2: wearing other protective gear such as leather or synthetic pants
column3: a jacket
column4: gloves
column5: and boots can help to minimise the risk of injuries in the event of a crash. These simple precautions can help to keep yourself safe on the road.

column2: Helvetica
column3: sans-serif; line-height: 1.2; margin-top: 10pt; margin-bottom: 10pt;""><strong><span style=""font-size: 14pt; font-family: Calibri
column4: sans-serif; background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Obey The Speed Limit

column1: The speed limit is there for a reason. Obeying the posted limit can help prevent motorcycle accidents. Higher speeds increase the chances of losing control of the bike and make it more difficult to stop or avoid obstacles.
In addition
column2: speeding makes it more likely that other motorists will not see the motorcycle in time to avoid an accident. And if an accident does occur
column3: the faster the bike is going
column4: the more serious the injuries are likely to be. So
column5: whether you are out for an easy ride or trying to get somewhere in a hurry
column6: obey the speed limit and help keep everyone safe on the road.

column1: Read Top 10 ABS Motorbikes in Bangladesh

column2: Helvetica
column3: sans-serif; line-height: 1.2; margin-top: 10pt; margin-bottom: 10pt;""><strong><span style=""font-size: 14pt; font-family: Calibri
column4: sans-serif; background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Be Aware of Your Surroundings

column1: Motorcycle accidents can happen in the blink of an eye and often result in serious injuries or even death. In order to help prevent these accidents
column2: it is important to be aware of your surroundings at all times when riding.

column1: Pay attention to the road ahead and be on the lookout for potential hazards
column2: such as potholes
column3: debris
column4: or sudden changes in the weather. If you see something that could potentially cause an accident
column5: slow down and proceed with caution.

column2: Helvetica
column3: sans-serif; line-height: 1.2; margin-top: 10pt; margin-bottom: 10pt;""><strong><span style=""font-size: 14pt; font-family: Calibri
column4: sans-serif; background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Use Turn Signals

column1: Many people enjoy the freedom and independence that comes with motorcycle riding; this can be dangerous as accidents are all too common. One way to help prevent motorcycle accidents is to use turn signals.

Turn signals give other drivers a heads up about your intentions
column2: and they can help avoid potential collisions. In addition
column3: turn signals can also help you communicate with other riders in your group. So
column4: whether you are going for a leisurely ride or hitting the open road
column5: be sure to use your turn signals to help prevent motorcycle accidents.

column2: Helvetica
column3: sans-serif; line-height: 1.2; margin-top: 10pt; margin-bottom: 10pt;""><strong><span style=""font-size: 14pt; font-family: Calibri
column4: sans-serif; background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Stay Visible

column1: One of the best ways to prevent motorcycle accidents is to make sure that you are visible to other motorists. Wearing bright clothing and using reflective materials can help to make you more visible
column2: especially at night or in poor weather conditions.

column1: Additionally
column2: mounting reflective strips on your motorcycle can also help to increase your visibility. By taking these simple steps
column3: you can help to make sure that you arrive at your destination safely.

column4: sans-serif; background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Avoid Distractions

column1: Another effective way to avoid an accident is to stay focused on the task at hand: driving. Unfortunately
column2: this can be easier said than done. Distractions like cell phones
column3: other vehicles
column4: and even scenic views can take your attention away from the road ahead. That is why it is so important to be aware of your surroundings and keep your eyes on the road at all times.

column1: By remaining attentive
column2: you can help make sure that everyone enjoys safe and accident-free roads.

column1: As any motorcycle enthusiast knows
column2: there is nothing quite like the feeling of freedom on the open road. However
column3: this sense of freedom comes with a responsibility to practise safe riding habits. It may be tempting to show off your skills
column4: but it is much better to stumble on the side of caution.

By following all the rules and safe riding habits
column2: you can help to prevent motorcycle accidents and enjoy many happy miles on the open road.

column3: sans-serif; line-height: 1.2; margin-top: 10pt; margin-bottom: 10pt;""><strong><span style=""font-size: 14pt; font-family: Calibri
column4: sans-serif; background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Perform Regular Maintenance

column1: Accidents are inevitable. But there are some accidents that can be prevented with a bit of care and attention. Motorcycle accidents
column2: for example
column3: often occur due to negligence on the part of the rider. Improper maintenance of the bike can lead to brake failure
column4: tire blowouts
column5: and other problems that can cause an accident.

column1: That is why it is important to perform regular maintenance on your motorcycle
column2: including checking the tire pressure
column3: brakes
column4: and engine oil levels. By taking a few minutes to do this simple maintenance
column5: you can help prevent a potentially fatal accident.

column1: Last but not least
column2: riding a motorcycle while impaired can be extremely dangerous. Do not drink and ride under any circumstances. This is agist the law and very dangerous even though you are an excellent rider.

column6: helmets can also help to protect your face from the elements and from flying debris. When choosing a helmet
column7: be sure to select one that meets DOT safety standards and that fits snugly on your head. Wearing a helmet is one of the best ways to reduce your risk of being injured in a motorcycle accident.Read Always Wear Protective GearIn addition to a helmet
column8: wearing other protective gear such as leather or synthetic pants
column9: a jacket
column10: gloves
column11: and boots can help to minimise the risk of injuries in the event of a crash. These simple precautions can help to keep yourself safe on the road.Obey The Speed LimitThe speed limit is there for a reason. Obeying the posted limit can help prevent motorcycle accidents. Higher speeds increase the chances of losing control of the bike and make it more difficult to stop or avoid obstacles. In addition
column12: speeding makes it more likely that other motorists will not see the motorcycle in time to avoid an accident. And if an accident does occur
column13: the faster the bike is going
column14: the more serious the injuries are likely to be. So
column15: whether you are out for an easy ride or trying to get somewhere in a hurry
column16: obey the speed limit and help keep everyone safe on the road.Read Be Aware of Your SurroundingsMotorcycle accidents can happen in the blink of an eye and often result in serious injuries or even death. In order to help prevent these accidents
column17: it is important to be aware of your surroundings at all times when riding. Pay attention to the road ahead and be on the lookout for potential hazards
column18: such as potholes
column19: debris
column20: or sudden changes in the weather. If you see something that could potentially cause an accident
column21: slow down and proceed with caution.Use Turn SignalsMany people enjoy the freedom and independence that comes with motorcycle riding; this can be dangerous as accidents are all too common. One way to help prevent motorcycle accidents is to use turn signals. Read Turn signals give other drivers a heads up about your intentions
column22: and they can help avoid potential collisions. In addition
column23: turn signals can also help you communicate with other riders in your group. So
column24: whether you are going for a leisurely ride or hitting the open road
column25: be sure to use your turn signals to help prevent motorcycle accidents.Stay VisibleOne of the best ways to prevent motorcycle accidents is to make sure that you are visible to other motorists. Wearing bright clothing and using reflective materials can help to make you more visible
column26: especially at night or in poor weather conditions. Additionally
column27: mounting reflective strips on your motorcycle can also help to increase your visibility. By taking these simple steps
column28: you can help to make sure that you arrive at your destination safely.Read Avoid DistractionsAnother effective way to avoid an accident is to stay focused on the task at hand: driving. Unfortunately
column29: this can be easier said than done. Distractions like cell phones
column30: other vehicles
column31: and even scenic views can take your attention away from the road ahead. That is why it is so important to be aware of your surroundings and keep your eyes on the road at all times.By remaining attentive
column32: you can help make sure that everyone enjoys safe and accident-free roads.Practise Smart Riding HabitsAs any motorcycle enthusiast knows
column33: there is nothing quite like the feeling of freedom on the open road. However
column34: this sense of freedom comes with a responsibility to practise safe riding habits. It may be tempting to show off your skills
column35: but it is much better to stumble on the side of caution. Read By following all the rules and safe riding habits
column36: you can help to prevent motorcycle accidents and enjoy many happy miles on the open road.Perform Regular MaintenanceAccidents are inevitable. But there are some accidents that can be prevented with a bit of care and attention. Motorcycle accidents

column38: often occur due to negligence on the part of the rider. Improper maintenance of the bike can lead to brake failure
column39: tire blowouts
column40: and other problems that can cause an accident. That is why it is important to perform regular maintenance on your motorcycle

column1: 20210917;20210918;Dhaka;Titas moves to overhaul ageing accident-prone pipelines in Dhaka city;"<div class=""text"">

Titas Gas Transmission and Distribution Company is going to take up a massive project to overhaul its age-old gas pipelines in Dhaka metropolitan city to make the flow more smooth and minimize risks of accidents.
Official sources said the plan for changing the ageing pipelines came to be regarded as the core needs amid a series of recent explosions and fire accidents blamed on faulty and leaking lines.
When a huge explosion killed at least six people and injured several others in Moghbazar in last June
column2: fire service officials suspected leakage in Titas gas line as the cause.

column2: in one of country’s worst gas explosions.
the issue of the leakage in pipelines also came to the attention of the authorities when Titas Gas started installing pre-paid meters in parts of the city.

column1: Titas officials said their teams found huge leakages in pipelines in both customers’ end as well as utility end when they worked for pre-paid gas meters in recent years.

column3: energy and mineral resources for approval.

column2: who is dealing with the plan

According to official sources at Power Grid Company of Bangladesh (PGCB)
column2: the fire broke out at the 132/33 kV grid substation around 4pm
column3: but it was not clear what caused the fire.

column2: several units of Fire Service and Civil Defence rushed to the spot and brought the fire under control at about 4:50pm
column3: the sources said.

column2: Rampura
column3: Jatrabari
column4: Lalbagh and Dhanmondi areas was severely disrupted following the fire.

column2: ” a PGCB official told UNB.
however
column3: said the substation was recently handed over to Dhaka Power Distribution Company (DPDC).

column2: ” he said.

column1: 20200503;NA;Dhaka;211 killed in road crashes in one month despite ‘lockdown’;"<div class=""text"">
A total of 211 people were killed and 227 others injured in 201 road accidents across the country in the last one month amid the ‘lockdown’ enforced on March 26
column2: said Bangladesh Jatri Kalyan Samity
column3: a passengers’ welfare platform
column4: on Sunday.

column1: Jatri Kalyan Samity came up with the statistics in a press statement after monitoring local
column2: regional and online newspapers.
50 drivers
column3: 64 pedestrians
column4: 22 women
column5: 12 students
column6: two transport workers
column7: 18 children
column8: one activist from political party
column9: two members of law enforcement agencies
column10: three teachers and one journalist were among those who died during the period.

column2: 14 people were killed and five others injured in 13 road accidents on April 23
column3: showing the highest number of accidents in just one day
column4: the release added.

column1: It said eight people were killed and two others injured in eight accidents occurred on waterways during this period.

column2: the government declared general holidays from March 26 to April 4
column3: aiming to protect people from being infected by the fast spreading virus as elsewhere in the world.

column2: the holidays were extended five times until April 25 -- first from April 5 to April 9
column3: then from April 10 to April 14
column4: later from April 15 to April 16
column5: then again from April 17 to April 25 and finally from April 25 to May 5.

column1: It also suspended mass transport operation to tackle the coronavirus outbreak.

BNP Standing Committee member Amir Khasru Mahmud Chowdhury and some leaders of the party’s Chattogram City unit had a close call when a lift crashed at the Chattogram Medical College Hospital (CMCH) in the city.
The BNP leaders had been to the hospital to visit those injured in Sunday’s gas pipeline blast that also left seven people dead at Patharghata in the city.
Amir Khasru said he had taken lift 3 along with some other party leaders to get down from the fifth floor of the hospital around 1:50pm when the accident occurred. “Luckily
column2: no-one was injured
column3: ” he said.

column1: Lift operator Sattyapriyo Barua said “technical problem” caused the lift to crash.

column2: Khasru was accompanied
column3: among others
column4: by Chattogram City unit BNP President Dr Shahadat Hossain
column5: Vice-President MA Aziz
column6: Senior Joint General Secretary SM Saiful Islam
column7: Joint Secretary Yasin Chowdhury Liton and former president of Jubo Dal Kazi Belal.

column2: June 10 (UNB) - A total of 142 people were killed and 324 others injured in 95 road accidents across the country during Eid journeys over the last 11 days till Sunday
column3: making it clear that bus journeys in the country are far more dangerous than it is anticipated.

column1: The accidents took place from May 30 and June 9 on roads
column2: highways
column3: and inter-district and regional roads across the country
column4: including the capital
column5: said a report released by National Committee to Protect Shipping
column6: Roads and Railways (NCPSRR) on Monday.

column2: online news portals
column3: news agencies and television channels
column4: it said.

column1: The report said the transport management on roads and waterways was comparatively better during this Eid than a few years ago.
Almost all the highways were free from gridlocks while there were enough launches in Dhaka to carry homebound people to coastal areas
column2: it said.
Eid holidaymakers were
column3: however
column4: deprived of desired services from the railway authorities for the schedule collapse of trains.

column2: the authorities concerned failed to check exorbitant bus and launch fares charged from passengers
column3: the NCPSRR said.

column1: It said seven people were killed and eight others received injuries in seven accidents on May 30 while six killed and seven injured in six accidents on May 31.

column3: at least 13 people embraced death and 14 others sustained injuries in seven accidents.

26 killed and 78 injured in 16 accidents on June 5
column2: the Eid day
column3: 11 killed and 33 wounded in eight road crashes on June 6 and 11 killed and 18 others injured in six accidents on June 7.

column1: Eight people lost their lives on roads and 11 others received injuries in seven accidents on June 8 while six accidents took place on June 9 when five were killed and 24 others injured.

column2: general secretary of the NCPSRR
column3: told UNB that they have identified six vital reasons for accidents during the Eid holydays.

column1: The reasons include speedy driving to recoup time lost in several ferry ghats and toll stations
column2: reckless driving on free roads
column3: negligence by traffic policemen
column4: drivers’ absent mindedness while driving vehicles for pressure from passengers to drop them to their destinations on time
column5: physical and mental unfitness of drivers for making extra trips
column6: tendency to violate traffic rules while overtaking and free movement of three-wheeled vehicles and motorbikes on highways and inter-district roads.

column1: Locals said Tahsin and Tamjid fell into the pond while playing on its bank near their house and drowned around noon – the very same pattern that is found behind the deaths of thousands of other minors in Bangladesh every year.

column1: 20190329;NA;NA;FR tower fire: Four probe bodies formed;"<div class=""text"">

column2: Mar 28 (UNB) – Four committees have already been formed to investigate the deadly fire incident at a high-rise building in the capital’s Banani commercial area on Thursday afternoon that killed at least 19 people.

column1: A six-member probe body was formed by the Home Ministry keeping additional secretary of the ministry’s security services division Dr Tarun Kanti Shikder as convener to investigate the fire and give details of the entire incident.
The committee was asked to look into the incident on the ground and submit the report along with the suggestions to avoid such incidents within seven days
column2: said a press release of Home Ministry.
kol.jpg"" style=""height:680px; width:1200px""/>

column1: The Fire Service and Civil Defence formed a five-member committee to investigate the fire incident.
Ministry of Disaster Management formed an eight-member probe body to investigate the fire incident.
A seven-member probe body was formed by the Housing and Public Works Ministry to look into whether approval of FR Tower building design and its subsequent construction was faulty or not.
The committee was asked to submit its report in seven working days
column2: said a press release of the ministry.

column2: bad runway approach blamed for US-Bangla crash;"<div class=""text"">
Jan 28 (UNB) – The US-Bangla Airlines aircraft was misaligned with the runway and its pilot was disoriented and tried to land in ""sheer desperation"" when it crashed last year in Nepal
column3: said Nepal’s investigation report.

column2: Bangladesh’s lone representative to the investigation commission Salauddin M Rahmatullah said the report only blamed the pilot without mentioning the faults of the Air Traffic Control (ATC) of Tribhuvan International Airport.

column1: The US-Bangla Airlines flight BS211 from Dhaka crashed on its second landing attempt at Kathmandu's Tribhuvan International Airport on March 12
column3: killing 51 people
column4: including the pilot and co-pilot
column5: and injuring 20 others.

column1: The investigation report compiled by Nepalese officials and made available Monday said the probable cause of the crash was the pilot's disorientation and loss of situation awareness
column2: reports AP.
""Contributing to this
column3: the aircraft was offset to the proper approach path that led to maneuvers in a very dangerous and unsafe altitude to alight with the runway. Landing was completed in a sheer desperation after sighting the runway
column4: at very close proximity and very low altitude.”

column1: It also said the pilot had been released from the Bangladesh Air Force in 1993 due to depression and was only allowed to fly civilian planes from 2002 after a detailed medical evaluation.

column2: the pilot was under stress and emotionally disturbed and had lack of sleep in the preceding night.

column1: The report also cited a lack of assertiveness from controllers at Kathmandu airport in monitoring the flight path and failing to issue clear instructions to carry out a standard missed-approach procedure.
The flight crew and the controllers also lacked a clear understanding of each other when they communicated about the landing runway
column2: the report said.

column1: The report recommended that assertiveness in such situations become part of the training for air traffic controllers.

It also asked the Bangladesh civil aviation authority to reassess the physical and psychological status of grounded pilots before their licenses are renewed and that all airline pilots undergo psychological evaluation during training.

column2: also Flight Operation Consultant of Civil Aviation Authority of Bangladesh (CAAB)
column3: briefed reporters over the report in Dhaka on Monday.

column2: “The pilot missed the approach while landing the aircraft. Although the ATC could have assisted the pilot
column3: they didn’t do so. Rather the ATC officials took shelter under the table when the plane crashed near the ATC tower.”

column2: two pilots on ground requested the ATC to assist the pilot through the radar. But the ATC didn’t take any measure in this regard. Had the ATC assisted the pilot
column3: the accident could have been averted
column4: ” the CAAB official said.

column1: He said Bangladesh will put forward some proposals for incorporation in the report. “If the proposals are not included
column2: Bangladesh will lodge complaint with the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO)
column3: ” he said.

column1: CAAB Chairman Air Vice Marshal M Naim Hassan said the pilot somehow missed the approach
column2: but it was the duty of the ATC to assist him. “They (ATC officials) didn’t do so.”

column12: said BIWTA Chairman Commodore Mozammel Haque from the spot.He also said they brought more equipment from the capital to be sure to this end.Meanwhile
column13: an eight-member team of Bangladesh Navy divers and BIWTA rescue ship ‘Pratya’ went to the spot in the afternoon to join the savage operation
column14: said Deputy Commissioner Saila Farzana from the spot.She said the rescue operation for Thursday was suspended in the evening for Thursday and it will resume on Friday morning again.The DC also said the Navy members and the ship will start work on Friday morning.She said the rescuers were facing trouble in locating the trawler as it capsized at night and all the workers were sleep when the incident happened.Meanwhile
column15: the air of the riverbank became heavier with the wails of the relatives of the missing workers who were desperately looking for their loved ones.The relatives thronged the riverbank for news on the fate of the trawler capsize victims.

column1: 20181029;20181029;NA;Thai owner of Leicester soccer team died in helicopter crash;"<div class=""text"">

column2: Oct 29 (AP/UNB) — Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha achieved what seemed impossible in modern soccer: Gaining promotion with a modest club and winning the English Premier League title within two years.

column1: Bankrolling Leicester City but without the lavish spending of the bigger clubs
column2: the Thai billionaire oversaw one of the greatest underdog successes in sports when the 5
column3: 000-1 outsiders won soccer's richest competition in 2016.

column1: In an era of often-absentee foreign owners in the Premier League
column2: Vichai also broke the mold by forging close ties with supporters and the local community.

column1: While Vichai did not seek the limelight and was far from flamboyant
column2: the wealthy entrepreneur's grandiose mode of transport from the King Power stadium named after his duty-free empire became symbolic of the club's newfound status in the game. A helicopter would land on the field after matches and whisk away the owner.

column1: Saturday night was the last journey for Vichai.
Goalkeeper Kasper Schmeichel was seen weeping as he stared at a fireball in a carpark outside the stadium around an hour after a 1-1 draw with West Ham. Moments earlier
column2: the AgustaWestland AW169 had risen from the center circle and cleared the stadium roof before it spiraled out of control and plummeted into an adjacent carpark in flames.

column1: The 60-year-old Vichai and the four other people on board did not survive the inferno
column2: Leicester announced Sunday.

column1: ""I am so totally devastated. I just cannot believe what I saw last night
column2: Schmeichel said. In an emotional tribute to Vichai
column3: the seven-year veteran of the club said: ""You changed football. Forever. You gave hope to everyone that the impossible was possible
column4: not just to our fans but to fans all over the world in any sport.""

column1: On the spot where fans danced into the night after the improbable title victory two years ago
column2: people gathered through the day to mourn. Hours before the Sunday night confirmation that Vichai did not survive the crash
column3: scarves
column4: jerseys and flowers were laid in an ever-expanding memorial in front of the stadium.

column2: read one message on a club flag
column3: ""the dream wouldn't have become reality.""

column2: which had been scheduled for Tuesday against Southampton in the League Cup
column3: has been postponed.

column1: ""We now have a responsibility as a club
column2: as players and fans to honor you
column3: Schmeichel said.

column2: Nursara Suknamai and Kaveporn Punpare
column3: also died along with pilot Eric Swaffer and passenger Izabela Roza Lechowicz. Fears that family members were on board were allayed through the day
column4: with his Vichai's son
column5: Aiyawatt
column6: now in line to step up from his role as vice chairman.

column1: ""The world has lost a great man
column2: the Leicester club said in a statement. ""A man of kindness
column3: of generosity and a man whose life was defined by the love he devoted to his family and those he so successfully led.""

column2: who started with one shop and grew Thailand's massive King Power duty-free chain
column3: bought Leicester for 39 million pounds ($50 million) in 2010 when it was in the second-tier competition. Avoiding relegation in its first season back in the Premier League was remarkable enough in 2015 after spending much time in last place. But that was eclipsed in 2016 by the team winning the top-flight title for the first time since being founded in 1884.

column1: ""I always believed in the power of our spirit
column2: Vichai said at the time. ""It drove us to reach the Premier League
column3: it gave us the strength to stay in the Premier League
column4: and now it has inspired us to win the Premier League.

column1: ""It is a spirit that has spread beyond Leicester
column2: taking our story to the hearts of the world. Our spirit exists because of the love we share for each other and the energy it helps to create
column3: both on and off the pitch
column4: and in the years to come
column5: it will continue to be our greatest asset.""

column1: Vichai was ridiculed for hiring the manager who masterminded the title success. Claudio Ranieri had been out of work since being fired by the weak Greece national team and his only job in the Premier League at Chelsea ended 11 years earlier. But it proved to be an inspired recruitment
column2: helping to turn a humdrum group of journeymen and modestly purchased signings into a lineup that overpowered the mega-rich giants of the Premier League.
life-long supporter Ian Hubber said outside the stadium on Sunday. ""This is a nightmare.""

column1: The outpouring of emotion at the stadium on Sunday reflected how highly the ownership is regarded in the city
column2: which has only one professional soccer team. Vichai has formed a close bond with the fans
column3: sometimes mingling with them at games.

column1: Vichai has been praised for his charity work
column2: donating 2 million pounds ($2.5 million) toward a new local children's hospital
column3: and he often provided free beer and food for fans outside games.

column1: ""He's an owner who actually cared about a club
column2: 19-year-old fan Rikesh Vaja said. ""It's not just the club. He impacted the entire city.""

column1: He also gained for the club new fans in Thailand
column2: where they mourned Vichai's sudden death.
soccer fan Chatworachet Sae-Kow said in Bangkok. ""It brought fame to Thailand when they won (the title). He carried the Thai flag with him and made people know more about Thailand.""

column4: and the injured are Moudud Ahmed

column1: 20181022;20181023;NA;Qatar Airways: Gearbox failure forces emergency landing at Shahjalal;"<div class=""text"">

column2: Oct 22 (UNB) – A Qatar Airways flight made an emergency landing with about three hundred passengers on board at Hazrat Shahjalal International Airport (HSIA) here on Monday night after one of its landing gear failed.

column1: No one was hurt in the incident as all the passengers came out of it safely after it made an emergency landing around 9:40 pm
column2: HSIA director Group Captain Adullah-al-Faruq told UNB.

column1: The aircraft took off for Doha around 7:40 pm
column2: said Fire Service and Civil Defence Director Major AKM Shakil Newaj.
the pilot of the aircraft informed the HSIA control tower that there was some malfunction with one of its landing gear as it was not closing
column3: he said.

column2: the aircraft roamed in the air for around two hours to burn fuel
column3: in doing so making itself suitably light for the emergency landing.

Oct 22 (UNB) – A Qatar Airways flight made an emergency landing with about three hundred passengers on board at Hazrat Shahjalal International Airport (HSIA) here on Monday night after one of its landing gear failed. No one was hurt in the incident as all the passengers came out of it safely after it made an emergency landing around 9:40 pm

column8: in doing so making itself suitably light for the emergency landing.Later
column9: the pilot executed the emergency landing once clearance was received from airport authorities.

however
column3: landed safely with all passengers and cabin crews unhurt.

column1: Sources at the Airport said the flight BG-601 took off from Hazrat Shahjalal International Airport at around 3:26 pm carrying 65 passengers from Dhaka.

column2: the pilot of the aircraft announced that there was a problem detected at one of its landing wheels. Hearing the announcement
column3: the passengers got panicky and several of them started crying
column4: said a passenger wishing to speak to UNB anonymously.

column1: He said the pilot managed to land it safely at around 4:30 pm in second attempt. He added
column2: “We have seen fire fighter units

column2: Deputy Director of Air Traffic Control of Hazrat Shah Jalal International Airport Shah Wahidur Rahman said they detected a portion of layer of landing wheels was lying on the runway after the flight took off.

column2: ” said Wahidur Rahman.
he said there are multiple layers in the landing wheel. Sometimes
column3: such type of incident (fall of a portion of layer) may occur
column4: which is a normal thing
column5: he claimed.

column2: he said adding that a replacement wheel be carried from Dhaka to Sylhet by another aircraft.

including 11 children
column3: and seven crewmembers on board made the emergency landing at the airport at 1:20 pm

column2: the passengers were unhurt

a four-member probe body was formed led by Captain Salahuddin M Rahmatullah

column2: reaction-time declines in firefighters;"<div class=""text"">
Sep 2 (AP/UNB) — Randy Brooks' son had a request three years ago: What could his dad do to make wildland firefighting safer?
a professor at the University of Idaho's College of Natural Resources who deals with wildland firefighting
column3: it was more of a command.

column2: Bo Brooks
column3: is a wildland firefighter who a few days earlier during that 2015 fire season fled a wall of flames that killed three of his fellow firefighters in eastern Washington.

column1: The result of the conversation was an online survey that drew some 400 firefighters who mostly identified mental and physical fatigue as the primary cause of injuries to firefighters who are often confronted with a changing
column2: dangerous environment.

column1: But a self-selecting online survey is not necessarily representative of what's happening in the field. So Randy Brooks decided to apply some science.

That led to an ongoing health-monitoring study involving wrist-worn motion monitors and body composition measurements that last year found health declines and deteriorating reaction times among firefighters as the season progressed.
""A lot of them face peer pressure to perform all the time
column2: Brooks said. ""Others feel pressured to protect natural resources and structures at all costs.""
000 firefighters are currently in the field fighting nearly 40 large wildfires. Fourteen firefighters have died this year as wildfires have scorched about 3
column3: 500 square miles (9
column4: 000 square kilometers) and destroyed about 3
column5: 000 homes.

column1: The study last year found firefighters lost muscle mass but gained fat based on body-composition testing before and after the season.

The firefighters also wore a wrist device called a Readiband from a company called Fatigue Science. The device keeps track of how many hours of sleep a person gets. Formulas developed by the U.S. military then calculate fatigue
column2: based on a lack of sleep. That's used to predict alertness and reaction times
column3: which get worse as fatigue levels rise.

column1: Firefighters in the field can get as little as six hours of sleep or less each night. The devices found that not only did reaction times falter as firefighters remained longer on a fire before getting a mandatory break
column2: Brooks said
column3: but firefighters also tended to take longer to recover as the season progressed. Sometimes
column4: fatigue levels reached a level that suggested reaction times slowed down so much it took firefighters twice as long to react.

column1: Brooks said his initial thoughts are that wildland firefighters might need better nutrition to stay fit and mentally sharp. But last year's study had only nine firefighters. Brooks this year has expanded the study to 18 firefighters
column2: 16 men and two women. They're smokejumpers
column3: meaning they parachute from airplanes to fight fires.

column1: Brooks said that next year he hopes to have about 100 firefighters and include hotshot crews
column2: a ground-based wildland firefighter that can
column3: like smokejumpers
column4: be deployed on a national basis.

column1: Smokejumpers in the study often eat pre-made meals. Brooks wants to find out if maybe those meals are behind some of the puzzling results from last year's study
column2: such as a loss in muscle mass.
meanwhile
column3: can return to a central spot where they get prepared food supplied by the U.S. Forest Service. That agency has done extensive research on what it takes to keep wildland firefighters fueled
column4: and contractors who supply the meals must meet Forest Service nutritional guidelines.

column1: Forest Service health experts have even followed firefighting crews to take blood samples to check glucose levels
column2: which can indicate alertness.
an exercise physiologist with the Forest Service's National Technology and Development Program in Missoula
column3: Montana
column4: said that experiment led the agency to change gears and recommend firefighters snack during their shifts to keep glucose levels up.

column1: ""It's critical for cognitive function as well as physical movement
column2: he said.

column1: The agency declined to comment on the University of Idaho study.
Brooks said at this point in his study there are more questions than answers. For example
column2: one question is why so many firefighter deaths are due to falling branches or trees. The deaths of three of the 14 firefighters who died last year were due to what are called hazard trees. At least one firefighter was killed by a falling tree this year
column3: and several more have been injured.

column1: ""What I'm trying to figure out is what is causing these accidents
column2: Brooks said.

column1: A fair number of wildland firefighters also die of heart attacks during the season. Brooks said he wants to know if there's something about the demanding seasonal job that puts wildland firefighters at greater risk of heart attacks.
Brooks wonders about the smoke firefighters inhale while doing physically demanding work. Many cities in the Pacific Northwest this year issued health alerts due to smoky air.

column2: firefighters themselves might be part of the problem when it comes to calculating risks while protecting natural resources and property.

column1: ""There's a little bit of a hero culture
column2: said John Freemuth
column3: a Boise State University environmental policy professor and public lands expert. ""There is a bonding with everybody. It can create a culture of where you kind of collectively ignore things you shouldn't ignore.""

column1: 20180901;NA;NA;Deadly New Mexico bus crash prompts negligence claims;"<div class=""text"">

column2: Sep 1 (AP/UNB) — A California-based trucking company and one of its drivers were accused of negligence Friday in a pair of lawsuits as investigators sorted through the wreckage from a deadly bus crash on a New Mexico highway. Eight people were killed and 25 injured
column3: including three young children.

column1: The Greyhound bus carrying nearly 50 people was headed west along Interstate 40 on Thursday when a semitrailer going in the opposite direction lost the tread on its left front tire and veered across a median and smashed into the bus
column2: police said.

column1: The front of the bus was mangled
column2: the cab of the semi was flipped and the trailer was on its side as debris was scattered across the highway. Passing motorists stopped to help passengers climb out of the wreckage before authorities arrived.

column1: New Mexico State Police Chief Pete Kassetas called them heroes
column2: saying some pulled ladders from trucks to reach the bus windows.

column1: ""For them to stop and get involved is amazing. I commend them
column2: the chief said. ""To get ladders
column3: to get into the bus to get people. Can you imagine?""

column1: Investigators with National Transportation Safety Board have secured the vehicles for inspection and examined the crash scene Friday. They also will be looking at factors such as driver fatigue
column2: training
column3: safety records and the condition of the roadway.

column1: ""Unfortunately things of this nature occur and our job is to try to do what we can do to prevent them from happening again in the future
column2: said lead investigator Pete Kotowski.

column1: The legal complaints filed Friday allege negligence on behalf of the unnamed truck driver and JAG Transportation Inc. They cite data from the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration that shows the company reported three crashes in the last 24 months.
Attorney Bryan Williams said there are concerns about proper maintenance and inspection of the truck's tires.
A woman who answered the phone at the company's office said no one was available to comment.
The plaintiffs are not named but one is from Arizona and the other is from Ohio.

column2: a 35 year-old man licensed out of California
column3: sustained non-life-threatening injuries. Authorities did not name him
column4: saying he was not currently  facing charges.

column1: Officials at University of New Mexico Hospital in Albuquerque said nine patients remain hospitalized there
column2: including three adults who are in intensive care
column3: one of whom is in critical condition. Two infants are also in intensive care.

column1: Some patients were expected to undergo surgery Friday and Saturday. While doctors declined to offer specifics
column2: they said the patients had injuries that ranged from head trauma to spinal fractures and broken bones.

column1: ""Several of them will have a long road of recovery ahead
column2: said Sonlee West
column3: director of the hospital's trauma unit. ""We have been in contact with family members of several of the patients
column4: and several of them have been able to talk to their families.""

column1: Other passengers were being treated at hospitals in the Gallup area
column2: about 30 miles (48 kilometers) from the crash site.

column1: Authorities said Friday they were working on identifying those who were killed through fingerprints and other means.
Greyhound spokeswoman Crystal Booker said in a statement Friday that the company was cooperating with authorities and will also conduct an investigation of its own.

column2: a number of people have lost their lives
column3: including our driver
column4: who had 27 years' experience with Greyhound. Our hearts are with all those affected by this incident
column5: she said.

column1: Authorities identified the bus driver as Luis Alvarez
column3: of Santa Teresa
column4: New Mexico.

column1: A pile of debris remained on the shoulder of the highway Friday
column2: but transportation crews had yet to clear it because it contained evidence and belongings from the bus passengers.

column2: Sept 2 (UNB) - A Sub-Inspector (SI) of Rupnagar police station was killed as a bus
column3: seized for a previous offence
column4: hit his motorcycle from rear side in the city’s  Mirpur Zoo Road area on Sunday afternoon.

column2: the OC said.

column2: Belal Hossain

column1: 20180901;NA;NA;Dhaka’s transport system suffers for lack of vision
column2: not for money: Experts;"<div class=""text"">
Sep 1 (UNB) - Though the country has made a good economic progress over the years
column3: urban experts think its capital city still lacks quality bus fleets matching people’s improved lifestyle.

column2: 000 public buses in the city are completely unfit for running in a capital city like Dhaka and those should be replaced with high quality and standard and comfortable ones working out a comprehensive phase-out plan like the one that replaced thousands of two-stroke auto-rickshaws with CNG-run ones in 2003.

however

column1: 20180826;NA;NA;Take action against those responsible for road mismanagement: Ershad;"<div class=""text"">

column2: Aug 26 (UNB) – Jatiya Party Chairman HM Ershad on Sunday urged the government to take action against those who have ‘failed’ to restore discipline on roads as what he says some 100 people were killed in road accidents across the country during the Eid vacation.
he also demanded that the family members of the victims be provided with due compensation.

column1: “People’s joy of eid faded due to the huge loss of lives on unsafe roads. The regular reports in newspapers on road accidents have manifested how dangerous the country’s road communication is
column2: ” he observed.

column1: Ershad expressed deep shock over the loss of lives of ‘over 100’ people in recent road accidents
column2: prayed for salvation of the departed souls and conveyed his profound sympathy to the bereaved family members.

column1: The Jatiya Party chief also wished the injured early recovery.

column2: reckless’: Nepali probe report;"<div class=""text"">
Aug 27 (UNB)- Captain Abid Sultan of US-Bangla Flight BS211 was going through tremendous ‘personal mental stress and anxiety
column3: and a series of erroneous decisions on his part that led to the crash of the flight’
column4: according to the details of an official investigation led by the Nepalese government.

column1: The pilot of the US-Bangla plane that crashed at Kathmandu’s Tribhuvan International Airport in March killing 51 people
column2: appears to have ‘lied’ to the control tower during the landing procedure and was smoking continuously inside the cockpit during the one-hour flight from Dhaka to Kathmandu
column3: said the report
column4: a copy of which was obtained by the Kathmandu Post.

column2: Sultan was engaged in ‘erratic behaviour’ that marked a departure from his usual character-signs that should have immediately raised red flags
column3: Nepali investigators concluded in the report.

column2: Sultan had confirmed that the plane’s landing gear was down and locked. “Gears down
column3: three greens
column4: ” the pilot said
column5: according to the report
column6: referring to the electrical indicator lights inside the cockpit.

column2: when co-pilot Prithula Rashid conducted a final landing checklist
column3: the landing gears were not down. Minutes later
column4: the plane carrying 67 passengers and four crew members burst into flames after missing the runway during its second landing attempt.

column1: The majority of the 22 Nepalis killed in the crash were medical students who had come home on a two-month leave before their final year results were published. Only 20 passengers survived the crash.
Investigators say Sultan had been ‘smoking cigarettes frequently’ during the hour-long flight from Dhaka to Kathmandu.

column2: who had clocked more than 5
column3: 500 flying hours
column4: had not disclosed to the airlines that he was a smoker
column5: leading investigators to conclude that Sultan was undergoing severe mental stress inside the cockpit.

column1: “When we analysed the conversation on the Cockpit Voice Recorder
column2: it was clear to us that the captain was harbouring severe mental stress. He also seemed to be fatigued and tired due to lack of sleep
column3: ” investigators wrote in the report. “He was crying on several occasions.”

column1: The voice recorder has captured nearly an hour-long conversation between the captain and his co-pilot in the cockpit
column2: further demonstrating Sultan’s ‘tensed mood’ throughout the flight and a ‘complete lack of situational awareness’
column3: according to the report.

column1: It was not clear whom the pilot was directing the statement at
column2: as the co-pilot was the only crew member present inside the cockpit during the flight.

column1: The report also shows that Sultan made multiple abusive statements toward a female colleague [another co-pilot in the company] who had questioned his reputation as an instructor
column2: and their relationship was a major topic of discussion throughout the flight. Records show that Rashid
column3: the co-pilot
column4: was a passive listener to Sultan’s story throughout the flight.

column1: “A cockpit is a place where personal conversations between colleagues are strictly prohibited when the aircraft is preparing to land or take off
column2: ” said Captain Shrawan Rijal of Nepal Airlines. “It’s a strictly enforced cockpit rule
column3: which instructs pilots to focus entirely on the aircraft’s operations.”

column2: according to details from the audio recorder
column3: the pilot broke down and said that he was “very upset and hurt by the behaviour of the female colleague” and that “she was the only reason he was leaving the company.”

column1: The captain had expressed his desire to resign a day before the accident
column2: the report says
column3: although he had not submitted any written documents. He said that he wished to continue on the job for three more months to complete training the co-pilots.

column1: Sultan had joined US-Bangla in 2015. Prior to flying commercial flights
column2: he had served in the Bangladesh Air Force
column3: and according to reports
column4: had a history of depression. While in the Bangladesh Air Force
column5: back in 1993
column6: he had been removed from active duty after a psychiatric assessment. But he was re-evaluated by a psychiatrist back on January 9
column8: and had been declared fit for flying.

column1: The report said that Sultan’s detail medical history was not reviewed by US-Bangla Airlines when he was hired.

column2: general manager and spokesperson for the US-Bangla Airlines
column3: declined the Post’s request for comment.

column2: the report clarifies that Sultan did not exhibit any recurring mental issues during the medical examinations from 2002 to 2018.

column1: “None of the medical reports that the committee reviewed from 2012 to 2017 mentioned any symptoms about depression
column2: ” the report said
column3: adding that during his routine medical evaluations
column4: he was declared fit and free from any symptoms of depression.

column1: Aviation officials are expected to make a summary of the report public at the end of August.

column2: Sultan then lit a cigarette
column3: when the aircraft had just under three minutes to start their initial approach. This
column4: the report says
column5: demonstrated complacency and gross negligence of procedural discipline on the pilot’s part.

column2: a footbridge and a speed-breaker will be set up in front of the college

column2: Jul 21 (UNB) – Strong current due to rough weather continued disrupting ferry services on two major routes on the River Padma on Saturday
column3: inflicting miseries to passengers and truckers.

column1: Thousands of passengers to and from the south and south-western districts faced ordeal from Friday to cross the Paturia-Daulatdia and the Shimulia-Kathalbari river routes.

column2: launch services have been suspended from 11 am on Saturday as well as ferry services were also being hampered due to the strong current in the River Padma.

column1: According to Bangladesh Inland Water Transport Authority (BIWTA) Aricha office
column2: launch service was halted to avoid any unwanted accidents while ferries were taking about double of its general timing to cross the route due to the bad weather.

column1: “If the weather remains poor till Sunday morning
column2: the launch service will remain halted but if the weather improves then the launch service will resume from 8 am on Sunday
column3: ” said Assistant Director (Traffic) Faridul Islam of BITWA in Aricha.

column1: At least three hundred vehicles have been stranded at Daulatdia ghat
column2: he added.

column1: A total of 16 ferries were in service in the route
column2: said Abu Abdullah Rony
column3: assistant manager of BIWTC
column4: Daulatdia.

column2: in Munshiganj
column3: nine among 16 ferries were in service in the Shimulia-Kathalbariroute.

column1: Around 600 vehicles were seen stuck in the Shimulia ghat till filing of this report on Saturday night
column2: witnesses said.
plying of seven dump ferries were suspended temporarily since Friday night while nine others were in service
column3: said Khandoker Khalid Assistant General Manager of BIWTC Mawa adding that the services will resume once the weather improves.

column1: Water Traffic Inspector of BIWTA Md Soleman said plying of small launches was halted but large ones were commuting to ease the suffering of the passengers.

column2: long tailbacks were formed at the ghat area
column3: said officer-in-charge of Mawa River Police outpost Arman Hossain.
